items.title: Trump says Intel has agreed to give US government a 10% stake
items.standfirst: Unprecedented deal comes after president demanded CEO Lip-Bu Tan to resign over his ties to Chinese firmsThe US government has taken an unprecedented 10% stake in Intel under a deal with the struggling chipmaker and is planning more such moves, according to Donald Trump and the commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick, the latest extraordinary intervention by the White House in corporate America.Lutnick wrote on X: “BIG NEWS: The United States of America now owns 10% of Intel, one of our great American technology companies. Thanks to Intel CEO @LipBuTan1 for striking a deal that’s fair to Intel and fair to the American People.” Continue reading...
items.content: Unprecedented deal comes after president demanded CEO Lip-Bu Tan to resign over his ties to Chinese firmsThe US government has taken an unprecedented 10% stake in Intel under a deal with the struggling chipmaker and is planning more such moves, according to Donald Trump and the commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick, the latest extraordinary intervention by the White House in corporate America.Lutnick wrote on X: “BIG NEWS: The United States of America now owns 10% of Intel, one of our great American technology companies. Thanks to Intel CEO @LipBuTan1 for striking a deal that’s fair to Intel and fair to the American People.” Continue reading...

items.title: US Takes Nearly 10% Intel Stake, Clinching Unorthodox Deal
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump sealed a deal that gives the US government a nearly 10% stake in Intel Corp., part of an unconventional bid to reinvigorate the beleaguered company and boost domestic chip manufacturing.
items.content: President Donald Trump sealed a deal that gives the US government a nearly 10% stake in Intel Corp., part of an unconventional bid to reinvigorate the beleaguered company and boost domestic chip manufacturing.

items.title: Trump Won’t Seek Equity From Chipmakers With US Investment Plans
items.standfirst: The Trump administration will not seek equity stakes in chipmakers like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and Micron Technology Inc. that are boosting their US investments, as talks continue on taking a stake in Intel Corp., a US official said.
items.content: The Trump administration will not seek equity stakes in chipmakers like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and Micron Technology Inc. that are boosting their US investments, as talks continue on taking a stake in Intel Corp., a US official said.

items.title: Trump Is Betting Big on Intel. Will the Chips Fall His Way?
items.standfirst: The Trump administration is aiming to take an equity stake in Intel, according to US commerce secretary Howard Lutnick. Experts say the unconventional deal could backfire.
items.content: The Trump administration is aiming to take an equity stake in Intel, according to US commerce secretary Howard Lutnick. Experts say the unconventional deal could backfire.

ai_summary: The US government will acquire a 10% stake in Intel, totaling an $8.9 billion investment.
President Trump announced the deal after a meeting with Intel CEO Lip Bu Tan.
The deal is an unprecedented intervention by the White House in corporate America.
Intel released a statement following Trump's announcement of the government stake.
The US government's investment gives it a direct equity stake in the chipmaker.

clusters.title: Details on FBI raid of former Trump adviser-turned-critic's home, office
clusters.neutral_headline: FBI searches home of former Trump advisor John Bolton

items.title: Details on FBI raid of former Trump adviser-turned-critic's home, office
items.standfirst: FBI officials searched both the Maryland home and Washington, D.C., office of President Trump's former national security adviser, John Bolton. The bureau said it was conducting "court-authorized activity" and that there was no threat to public safety. CBS News' Daniel Klaidman and Olivia Rinaldi report.
items.content: FBI officials searched both the Maryland home and Washington, D.C., office of President Trump's former national security adviser, John Bolton. The bureau said it was conducting "court-authorized activity" and that there was no threat to public safety. CBS News' Daniel Klaidman and Olivia Rinaldi report.

items.title: Trump calls former adviser John Bolton a "sleaze bag" as the FBI searches his home
items.standfirst: President Trump said he does not know anything about the FBI search of the home and office of his former national security adviser, John Bolton. He did take the opportunity to criticize him, calling Bolton a "sleaze bag." CBS News' Ed O'Keefe reports from the White House.
items.content: President Trump said he does not know anything about the FBI search of the home and office of his former national security adviser, John Bolton. He did take the opportunity to criticize him, calling Bolton a "sleaze bag." CBS News' Ed O'Keefe reports from the White House.

items.content: The FBI has raided the home of John Bolton, the former national security adviser to Donald Trump who has since become a staunch critic of the US president.

items.title: FBI searches home of Trump’s former adviser and current critic John Bolton
items.standfirst: John Bolton served as national security adviser during US President Donald Trump’s first term before quitting and facing scrutiny over a book he wrote about his time in government. The FBI raided his Maryland home Friday as part of a probe into the handling of classified records.
items.content: John Bolton served as national security adviser during US President Donald Trump’s first term before quitting and facing scrutiny over a book he wrote about his time in government. The FBI raided his Maryland home Friday as part of a probe into the handling of classified records.

ai_summary: The FBI searched the home and office of John Bolton, a former Trump national security advisor.
Bolton has become a vocal critic of former President Trump since leaving his position.
The FBI stated the search was court-authorized activity, with no public safety threat.
Trump called Bolton a "sleaze bag" in response to the FBI search of his home.
Bolton served as Trump's national security advisor during his first term in office.

items.title: Ghislaine Maxwell transcripts: Epstein associate says she ‘never’ saw Trump receive a massage – live
items.standfirst: Transcripts and audio recordings from Maxwell’s interviews with deputy attorney general Todd Blanche releasedGhislaine Maxwell interview transcript released by US justice departmentGhislaine Maxwell transcripts: what we know at a glanceAs we bring you more information about the reported FBI raid on John Bolton’s Maryland home, it’s worth pointing out that Bolton was stripped of his security clearance when Trump started his second term in office. The president also got rid of Bolton’s government detail, despite being the target of an assassination plot due to Bolton’s criticism of the Iranian regime.Bolton served as Trump’s third national security adviser in his first term in office, but has since become a vocal critic of the president. Less than an hour ago, a post from Bolton’s X account critiqued the state of negotiations between Russia and Ukraine. “Russia has not changed its goal: drag Ukraine into a new Russian Empire,” he wrote. “Meanwhile, meetings will continue because Trump wants a Nobel Peace Prize, but I don’t see these talks making any progress.” Continue reading...
items.content: Transcripts and audio recordings from Maxwell’s interviews with deputy attorney general Todd Blanche releasedGhislaine Maxwell interview transcript released by US justice departmentGhislaine Maxwell transcripts: what we know at a glanceAs we bring you more information about the reported FBI raid on John Bolton’s Maryland home, it’s worth pointing out that Bolton was stripped of his security clearance when Trump started his second term in office. The president also got rid of Bolton’s government detail, despite being the target of an assassination plot due to Bolton’s criticism of the Iranian regime.Bolton served as Trump’s third national security adviser in his first term in office, but has since become a vocal critic of the president. Less than an hour ago, a post from Bolton’s X account critiqued the state of negotiations between Russia and Ukraine. “Russia has not changed its goal: drag Ukraine into a new Russian Empire,” he wrote. “Meanwhile, meetings will continue because Trump wants a Nobel Peace Prize, but I don’t see these talks making any progress.” Continue reading...

items.title: Ghislaine Maxwell's interview on Epstein case released by DOJ
items.standfirst: The Justice Dept. released transcripts of Deputy AG Todd Blanche's two-day interview with convicted sex trafficker and Jeffrey Epstein associate Ghislaine Maxwell.
items.content: The Justice Dept. released transcripts of Deputy AG Todd Blanche's two-day interview with convicted sex trafficker and Jeffrey Epstein associate Ghislaine Maxwell.

items.title: Epstein records sent to House Oversight Committee
items.standfirst: The Department of Justice sent the first wave of Jeffrey Epstein case files to Congress on Friday. Plus, the DOJ released full transcripts and audios of Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche's two-day interview with Epstein associate Ghislaine Maxwell. Blanche met with Maxwell last month amid backlash over the Trump administration's handling of the Epstein case. CBS News congressional correspondent Nikole Killion reports.
items.content: The Department of Justice sent the first wave of Jeffrey Epstein case files to Congress on Friday. Plus, the DOJ released full transcripts and audios of Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche's two-day interview with Epstein associate Ghislaine Maxwell. Blanche met with Maxwell last month amid backlash over the Trump administration's handling of the Epstein case. CBS News congressional correspondent Nikole Killion reports.

items.title: Ghislaine Maxwell says she ‘never witnessed’ Trump in any inappropriate setting in DOJ tapes
items.standfirst: NBC News Law Enforcement and Intelligence Correspondent Tim Winter joins Meet the Press NOW with the latest on the Department of Justice releasing transcripts and tapes from their interviews with Jeffrey Epstein’s associate Ghislaine Maxwell.
items.content: NBC News Law Enforcement and Intelligence Correspondent Tim Winter joins Meet the Press NOW with the latest on the Department of Justice releasing transcripts and tapes from their interviews with Jeffrey Epstein’s associate Ghislaine Maxwell.

items.title: Read the full transcript of Ghislaine Maxwell's DOJ interviews
items.standfirst: See the full transcript of Ghislaine Maxwell's interview with Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche as renewed scrutiny falls on the Epstein files during Trump's presidency.
items.content: See the full transcript of Ghislaine Maxwell's interview with Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche as renewed scrutiny falls on the Epstein files during Trump's presidency.

items.title: Ghislaine Maxwell transcripts: what we know at a glance
items.standfirst: US justice department released transcripts of interview with Jeffrey Epstein associate – here’s what we have learnedThe US Department of Justice has released the transcripts and audio recording of an interview conducted by Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, with the convicted sex trafficker Ghislaine Maxwell.The transcripts include redacted documentation from a two-day interview on 24 and 25 July and several audio recordings. Here’s what we know so far at a glance:Maxwell said that she “never” saw Donald Trump receive a massage. She also said that she “never witnessed the president in any inappropriate setting in any way,” adding that, whenever she saw the president, he was “a gentleman in all respects”.One notable point is that Maxwell denied ever recruiting masseuses from Trump’s Mar-a-Lago club. “I’ve never recruited a masseuse from Mar-a-Lago for that, as far as I remember. I can’t ever recollect doing that,” she told Blanche. A reminder that Trump claimed his falling-out with Epstein stemmed from Epstein’s efforts to hire workers away from Trump’s Florida club.Maxwell detailed the social relationship between Trump and Epstein, who cultivated a wide and powerful social circle for many years. “I don’t know how they met, and I don’t know how they became friends. I certainly saw them together and I remember the few times I observed them together, but they were friendly. I mean, they seemed friendly,” she said.Maxwell also did not recall former US president Bill Clinton receiving a massage while travelling with Epstein.Blanche said, on the record, that the conversation was not “promising to do anything” for Maxwell. He said that anything she said could not be used against her, unless she provided false statements or there was a retrial in her case.According to Maxwell, Epstein did not have any video or photographic evidence of any high-profile individuals committing sexual offences. And to that point, Maxwell also said she didn’t hear or witness any instances of Epstein blackmailing powerful people.Maxwell said she recruited a number of masseuses for Epstein but “never checked their age or credentials”. She added that, throughout her time with Epstein, she never heard any examples of “sexually inappropriate contact” between Epstein’s guests and in-house masseuses.Despite her claims that Epstein did not extort anyone, Maxwell said she did not believe that Epstein died by suicide. She chalked that up to “mismanagement” at the Bureau of Prisons.In the interview, Maxwell said she did believe that Epstein “did a lot of, not all, but some of what he’s accused of”. But she maintained that “he became that man over a period of time”.Maxwell did not remember whether Trump submitted a letter for Epstein’s 50th birthday album, as reported by the Wall Street Journal. She also could not remember asking Trump to contribute.Maxwell said Hillary Clinton did not associate with Epstein. When Maxwell was asked if Epstein “knew or had any sort of visit, dealings or associated with Hillary Clinton,” Maxwell responded: “I would say no.” Continue reading...
items.content: US justice department released transcripts of interview with Jeffrey Epstein associate – here’s what we have learnedThe US Department of Justice has released the transcripts and audio recording of an interview conducted by Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, with the convicted sex trafficker Ghislaine Maxwell.The transcripts include redacted documentation from a two-day interview on 24 and 25 July and several audio recordings. Here’s what we know so far at a glance:Maxwell said that she “never” saw Donald Trump receive a massage. She also said that she “never witnessed the president in any inappropriate setting in any way,” adding that, whenever she saw the president, he was “a gentleman in all respects”.One notable point is that Maxwell denied ever recruiting masseuses from Trump’s Mar-a-Lago club. “I’ve never recruited a masseuse from Mar-a-Lago for that, as far as I remember. I can’t ever recollect doing that,” she told Blanche. A reminder that Trump claimed his falling-out with Epstein stemmed from Epstein’s efforts to hire workers away from Trump’s Florida club.Maxwell detailed the social relationship between Trump and Epstein, who cultivated a wide and powerful social circle for many years. “I don’t know how they met, and I don’t know how they became friends. I certainly saw them together and I remember the few times I observed them together, but they were friendly. I mean, they seemed friendly,” she said.Maxwell also did not recall former US president Bill Clinton receiving a massage while travelling with Epstein.Blanche said, on the record, that the conversation was not “promising to do anything” for Maxwell. He said that anything she said could not be used against her, unless she provided false statements or there was a retrial in her case.According to Maxwell, Epstein did not have any video or photographic evidence of any high-profile individuals committing sexual offences. And to that point, Maxwell also said she didn’t hear or witness any instances of Epstein blackmailing powerful people.Maxwell said she recruited a number of masseuses for Epstein but “never checked their age or credentials”. She added that, throughout her time with Epstein, she never heard any examples of “sexually inappropriate contact” between Epstein’s guests and in-house masseuses.Despite her claims that Epstein did not extort anyone, Maxwell said she did not believe that Epstein died by suicide. She chalked that up to “mismanagement” at the Bureau of Prisons.In the interview, Maxwell said she did believe that Epstein “did a lot of, not all, but some of what he’s accused of”. She also could not remember asking Trump to contribute.Maxwell said Hillary Clinton did not associate with Epstein. When Maxwell was asked if Epstein “knew or had any sort of visit, dealings or associated with Hillary Clinton,” Maxwell responded: “I would say no.” Continue reading...

Maxwell stated she "never" saw Trump receive a massage in the released transcripts.
The DOJ also sent the first wave of Jeffrey Epstein case files to the House Oversight Committee.

Bolton was stripped of his security clearance when Trump started his second term.

items.title: Canada will match US tariff exemptions under USMCA trade pact, Prime Minister Carney says
items.standfirst: TORONTO — Canada is dropping many of its retaliatory tariffs to match U.S. tariff exemptions for goods covered under the United States-Mexico-Canada trade pact, Prime Minister Mark Carney announced Friday. Carney said Canada will include the carve-out that the U.S. has on Canadian goods under the…
items.content: TORONTO — Canada is dropping many of its retaliatory tariffs to match U.S. tariff exemptions for goods covered under the United States-Mexico-Canada trade pact, Prime Minister Mark Carney announced Friday. Carney said Canada will include the carve-out that the U.S. has on Canadian goods under the…

items.title: Canada drops some retaliatory tariffs in bid to restart trade talks
items.standfirst: Carney said Canada will lift its tariffs on U.S. goods that comply with a North American free trade pact, but keep tariffs on U.S. steel, aluminum and autos.
items.content: Carney said Canada will lift its tariffs on U.S. goods that comply with a North American free trade pact, but keep tariffs on U.S. steel, aluminum and autos.

items.content: Prime Minister Mark Carney says most Canadian goods will be exempted from US tariffs while some sectoral duties remain.

items.title: Trump says 'We want to be very good to Canada,' as its leader drops some tariffs
items.standfirst: After Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney announced he would lower tariffs, President Trump said "We want to be very good to Canada. I like Carney a lot. I think he's a very good person."
items.content: After Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney announced he would lower tariffs, President Trump said "We want to be very good to Canada. I like Carney a lot. I think he's a very good person."(Image credit: Spencer Colby)

items.title: Canada to drop counter-tariffs on some US goods one day after call with Trump
items.standfirst: Mark Carney says change will go into effect on 1 September but tariffs on steel, aluminum and autos will remainCanada will drop its counter-tariffs on some American goods in the coming days, Mark Carney has said, as the country’s prime minister looks to end a protracted trade war with longtime ally the United States.From 1 September, the Canadian government will remove some levies on US goods that comply with the North American free-trade pact, a move meant to “match” how the White House treated Canadian goods. Levies on steel, aluminum and autos will remain in place. Continue reading...
items.content: Mark Carney says change will go into effect on 1 September but tariffs on steel, aluminum and autos will remainCanada will drop its counter-tariffs on some American goods in the coming days, Mark Carney has said, as the country’s prime minister looks to end a protracted trade war with longtime ally the United States.From 1 September, the Canadian government will remove some levies on US goods that comply with the North American free-trade pact, a move meant to “match” how the White House treated Canadian goods. Levies on steel, aluminum and autos will remain in place. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Canada will drop some retaliatory tariffs to match US tariff exemptions under USMCA.
Prime Minister Mark Carney announced the changes, effective September 1st.
Tariffs on steel, aluminum, and autos will remain in place.
The move aims to end a protracted trade war with the United States.
Trump said he likes Carney and wants to be good to Canada.

clusters.title: Former ambassador to Ukraine says there is more progress on Ukraine than it might seem

items.title: Former ambassador to Ukraine says there is more progress on Ukraine than it might seem
items.standfirst: Prospects for a summit between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, always dim, appear nearly non-existent. Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov told NBC News that a summit agenda is "not ready at all." Former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine William Taylor joins "The Takeout" to discuss.
items.content: Prospects for a summit between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, always dim, appear nearly non-existent. Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov told NBC News that a summit agenda is "not ready at all." Former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine William Taylor joins "The Takeout" to discuss.

items.title: Russia rejects Zelensky talks, Trump says setting up summit like mixing ‘oil and vinegar’
items.standfirst: Russia on Friday ruled out an immediate meeting between President Vladimir Putin and Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelensky, despite a claim by US President Donald Trump earlier this week that he was arranging a summit. Trump on Friday said setting up a Zelensky-Putin summit was as hard as mixing "oil and vinegar".
items.content: Russia on Friday ruled out an immediate meeting between President Vladimir Putin and Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelensky, despite a claim by US President Donald Trump earlier this week that he was arranging a summit. Trump on Friday said setting up a Zelensky-Putin summit was as hard as mixing "oil and vinegar".

items.title: Russia's foreign minister says no Putin-Zelenskyy summit planned despite Trump's peace push
items.standfirst: Russia’s top diplomat said Friday that no meeting is planned between President Vladimir Putin and Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelenskyy, casting new doubt on President Donald Trump’s push for a summit to end the war.“Putin is ready to meet with Zelenskyy when the agenda is ready for a summit, and this agenda is not ready at all,” Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov told NBC News’ “Meet the Press” moderator Kristen Welker in an exclusive interview
items.content: Russia’s top diplomat said Friday that no meeting is planned between President Vladimir Putin and Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelenskyy, casting new doubt on President Donald Trump’s push for a summit to end the war.“Putin is ready to meet with Zelenskyy when the agenda is ready for a summit, and this agenda is not ready at all,” Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov told NBC News’ “Meet the Press” moderator Kristen Welker in an exclusive interview

ai_summary: Russia ruled out an immediate meeting between Putin and Zelenskyy.

Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov said the summit agenda is not ready.

clusters.title: Colombia hit by deadly guerrilla attacks, at least 18 killed
clusters.neutral_headline: Deadly guerrilla attacks in Colombia kill 18

items.title: Colombia hit by deadly guerrilla attacks, at least 18 killed
items.standfirst: Two attacks by dissident guerrilla groups in Colombia killed 18 people and injured dozens on Thursday. A truck bomb struck Cali, while a drone downed a police helicopter at a northern coca farm, worsening the country’s worst security crisis in decades and threatening fragile peace efforts ahead of next year’s elections.
items.content: Two attacks by dissident guerrilla groups in Colombia killed 18 people and injured dozens on Thursday. A truck bomb struck Cali, while a drone downed a police helicopter at a northern coca farm, worsening the country’s worst security crisis in decades and threatening fragile peace efforts ahead of next year’s elections.

items.title: At least 18 killed and dozens injured in separate Colombia attacks
items.standfirst: A car bomb killed six people in Cali while a downed police helicopter left 12 officers dead.
items.content: A car bomb killed six people in Cali while a downed police helicopter left 12 officers dead.

items.title: Iran, European powers to resume nuclear talks as 'snapback' sanctions loom
items.standfirst: Ahead of an August 31 deadline imposed by France, Britain and Germany, to trigger a "snapback" sanctions mechanism, Iran on Friday agreed to resume nuclear talks with the "E3" European countries next week. The Israel-Iran war in June has added pressure on the European powers to reach a diplomatic solution to the Iranian nuclear issue.
